ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Met once a week in a synchronous seminar

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course introduced us to a broad range of topics, including the personal authority of the late Romanovs to Stalin, legal codes, surveillance, and military history. The course also prepared us well to produce a long research paper.
I greatly developed my writing skills, especially for writing history papers. I also developed good reading habits (reading lots of material quickly and getting the important information from it).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Interesting material, pretty good discussions
Weaknesses: The course structure. The material wasn't very cohesive, we kept jumping back and forth chronologically and switching between different topics. Each week felt very self-contained and the material didn't really build on itself over the course of the semester. I think I could have gotten a lot more out of the class if the course syllabus had been organized chronologically or if the material had been more clearly grouped thematically.
The arc of the course was not clear. It felt more like we discussed a variety of topics from week to week and I wasnt exactly sure what we were supposed to draw from it ultimately.
The strength of this class was definitely the reading assignments. They were all so fascinating and enlightening. The class itself, however, lacked structure at times and felt meandering.

The course was a good balance of discussions, readings, and papers. I like how at least 30% of our grade is based on participation and discussion posts. There could have been a little more guidance of what the professor was looking for in a presentation or paper, especially because that was such a big part of our grade.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The small class size and synchronous seminars were both conducive to learning online.
It was a small seminar, so it worked well over Zoom.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this class to someone who is interested in Russian history and has a strong background in the field. Some of the readings are really interesting but some are on fairly niche topics. Also, the syllabus bounces around between a lot of different topics and time periods over the course of the semester, which made it difficult to build on previous readings/discussions in each week's class. Overall, though, the class discussions were pretty interesting and engaging.
Yes. The course is definitely rigorous, but if you have an interest in Russian history, I highly recommend the class.
Yes, it covers a lot of information while incorporating really interesting and specific readings.
